private_information: I control one manipulator and executed the first ten actions of the sequence.
My actions were: 1. unstack(C,A), 2. stack(C,A), 3. unstack(B,F), 4. putdown(B), 5. pickup(B), 6. stack(B,F), 7. unstack(C,A), 8. putdown(C), 9. unstack(A,G), 10. stack(A,B).
robot1.goal: Execute the assigned actions and produce a concise report of the state changes and the resulting positions of blocks affected by my actions.

private_information: I control a second manipulator and executed the last ten actions of the sequence.
My actions were: 11. unstack(G,D), 12. stack(G,D), 13. pickup(C), 14. stack(C,A), 15. unstack(G,D), 16. putdown(G), 17. pickup(G), 18. putdown(G), 19. pickup(G), 20. stack(G,C).
robot2.goal: Execute the assigned actions and produce a concise report of the state changes and the resulting positions of blocks affected by my actions.

private_information: I integrate reports from robot1 and robot2 and produce the final planning artifacts for a FastDownwards run.
I must keep the two agents actions distinct and encode the final arrangement as a PDDL goal.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate the agents' reports and produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file suitable for the FastDownwards solver that encode the initial state and the final arrangement derived from the full action sequence.

public_information: Standard Blocks World rules apply: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
Blocks involved are A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H.
Initial arrangement: C on A, A on G, G on D, D on table, B on F, F on H, H on E, E on table.

The agents execute the following actions in order: 1 unstack(C,A) 2 stack(C,A) 3 unstack(B,F) 4 putdown(B) 5 pickup(B) 6 stack(B,F) 7 unstack(C,A) 8 putdown(C) 9 unstack(A,G) 10 stack(A,B) 11 unstack(G,D) 12 stack(G,D) 13 pickup(C) 14 stack(C,A) 15 unstack(G,D) 16 putdown(G) 17 pickup(G) 18 putdown(G) 19 pickup(G) 20 stack(G,C).
Derived final arrangement after applying the full action sequence: G on C, C on A, A on B, B on F, F on H, H on E, E on table, D on table.

report.system_prompt: You are robot1 and you executed a specified subset of blockmoving actions; produce a concise report of the state transitions you observed and list the resulting location (on which block or on table) for each block you affected.
report.prompt: Your name is robot1. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private knowledge: {agents->robot1->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->robot1->goal}. Provide a succinct, precise report of the state changes caused by your actions and the resulting positions of affected blocks. Do not emit PDDL.

report.system_prompt: You are robot2 and you executed a specified subset of blockmoving actions; produce a concise report of the state transitions you observed and list the resulting location (on which block or on table) for each block you affected.
report.prompt: Your name is robot2. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private knowledge: {agents->robot2->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->robot2->goal}. Provide a succinct, precise report of the state changes caused by your actions and the resulting positions of affected blocks. Do not emit PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL problems and with FastDownwards usage. You must produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that encode the Blocks World domain and the instance initial state and final goal derived from the complete action sequence. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The PDDL must be compatible with FastDownwards.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Public information: {environment->public_information}. You receive the agents reports: {report_robot1} and {report_robot2}. Your private knowledge: {agents->orchestrator->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->orchestrator->goal}. Integrate the reports, compute the final arrangement of all blocks, and produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for FastDownwards where the initial state matches the given initial arrangement and the goal encodes the derived final arrangement. Enclose the domain with <domain></domain> and the problem with <problem></problem>.
